articles.headline: Bending Ears on Economics as ’08 Nears
articles.snippet: The selection of economic advisers by the top presidential candidates reveals policy differences among Democrats.
articles.abstract: The selection of economic advisers by the top presidential candidates reveals policy differences among Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Barack Obama and John Edwards are aggressively pitting themselves against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But when it comes to something as fundamental as economic policy, the lineup quietly shifts: It is Senators Obama and Clinton against Mr. Edwards.

articles.headline: In a Surprise, Pat Robertson Backs Giuliani
articles.snippet: The endorsement exemplified the Christian conservative movement’s divide over balancing politics and principle.
articles.abstract: The endorsement exemplified the Christian conservative movement’s divide over balancing politics and principle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  They could compete for strangest bedfellows of 2008.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Homeowners Feel the Pinch of Lost Equity
articles.snippet: In an ominous portent for the national economy, which is largely based on consumer spending, fewer people can borrow against the value of their homes.
articles.abstract: In an ominous portent for the national economy, which is largely based on consumer spending, fewer people can borrow against the value of their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev., Nov. 5 — As his wedding day approached last spring, Marshall Whittey found that his money could not keep pace with the grandiosity of his plans. But rather than scale back, he chose instead, like millions of homeowners across the country, to borrow against the soaring value of his home.

articles.headline: Unseasonably Higher, Gas Prices Add to Strain on U.S. Consumers
articles.snippet: Gas prices usually drop in the fall, but prices at the pump are over $3 a gallon on average and rising. That could curb consumer spending at a critical time for retailers.
articles.abstract: Gas prices usually drop in the fall, but prices at the pump are over $3 a gallon on average and rising. That could curb consumer spending at a critical time for retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Nov. 7 — Most years, the shorter days and lower temperatures of autumn mean falling gasoline prices, as demand eases from the busy summer travel season.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Attempt  at 2 Steps Forward Is Taken One Back
articles.snippet: The automaker reported a $39-billion loss after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.
articles.abstract: The automaker reported a $39-billion loss after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Nearly two years ago, amid speculation of a potential bankruptcy filing, General Motors unveiled details of its reorganization plan and vowed to end the crisis that had enveloped the company.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Takes a Hit on Mortgages
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley, its stock buffeted in recent days by speculation of high credit losses, said yesterday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.

articles.headline: U.S. Prods Musharraf to End Emergency Rule
articles.snippet: The Bush administration is contacting army generals in Pakistan and encouraging back-channel negotiations.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration is contacting army generals in Pakistan and encouraging back-channel negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez, Helene Cooper and Steven Lee Myers, and written by Mr. Rohde.

articles.headline: Sleuthing for a Danger in Toy Beads
articles.snippet: A biochemical geneticist’s story demonstrates how recalls come about, in a time when they are becoming routine.
articles.abstract: A biochemical geneticist’s story demonstrates how recalls come about, in a time when they are becoming routine.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 8 — The story started with a 2-year-old boy who was taken to a suburban Sydney hospital on Oct. 5 in a shallow coma and suffering from seizurelike spasms. It ended with the latest recall of a Chinese-made toy, as the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered the recall of 4.2 million Aqua Dots in the United States on Wednesday evening.

articles.headline: Reaching for Apple, Falling Short
articles.snippet: T-Mobile’s new Shadow smartphone is supposed to be a communications powerhouse, but there are some drawbacks.
articles.abstract: T-Mobile’s new Shadow smartphone is supposed to be a communications powerhouse, but there are some drawbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iPhone’s biggest achievement isn’t any particular feature; it’s the way Apple took veto power away from the cellphone carriers.

articles.headline: Markets and Dollar Sink as Slowdown Worry Increases
articles.snippet: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar fell as investors grew skittish over oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar fell as investors grew skittish over oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro yesterday as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Peter S. Goodman
